This is an OS limitation. You ran out of handles and there was nothing else we 
could do.

Really?  I find it hard to believe that the only course of action is to crash
and you find this to be valid behavior.  

Before opening a file - i assume it is possible - you could check to see if
there are any handles left, if there are not then popup a dialog saying you must
close some files and refuse to open any more files at that point.

I have encountered this problem 4 times today on 3.0M3 (Windows XP Prof). 
Having Eclipse crash for such a problem is unacceptable. Eclipse itself seems 
to be out of control handles. Is Eclipse failing to free them? I am not doing 
anything out of the ordinary -- simply debugging an application. I didn't 
start encountering this problem until I upgraded to 3.0M3. Here is the 
beginning of the error log:

!MESSAGE No more handles
!STACK 0
org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles
	at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2393)
	at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2297)

(StatusTextEditor.java:47)
	at org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.ExtendedTextEditor.createPartControl
(ExtendedTextEditor.java:259)
...

This is a bug -- not an enhansement request. It is a showstopper for me. 
Eclipse crashes with this error repeatedly when a breakpoint is reached in my 
application. I even resorted to closing several unrelated projects to reduce 
the resource requirements, but it didn't help. A workaround would be much 
appreciated!

Could you answer the following:

1) do you run out of handles when debugging any application or just a certain 
application?  If it is only a particular app what is it doing?

2) Are you asking for Eclipse to do a better job at reporting the situation, 
or are you implying that it is eclipse which is using up all your resources 
and that it should not do this?

1) The problem happens only when debugging one application -- the one that 
I've been using Eclipse on for over a year. When the breakpoint is hit, 
massive disk activity occurs as if major page faults are happening(I have 512 
Meg of ram). The panels flicker. After about 3 to 5 minutes, Eclipse dies. 
The ".log" files reports the "No more handles" fault.

2) I suspect that Eclipse is consuming control handles and failing to free 
them. I have no other explanation since my application is not pathalogically 
large. If I am wrong, and the problem is due to some limit that I have 
exceeded some place, Eclipse should pop up a dialog box with an explanation 
and what I need to do to eliminate the problem.

I found the work-around: close all editor windows before starting the 
debugger! The 5-minutes of flicker and the crash no longer occur.

If I were to recreate this situation what would I do?

- create a sample app
- open N editor windows of type X 
- modify the contents of X editors
- attempt to debutg???

Perhaps it is that simple. I always have a large number of editor windows open 
and I have frequently encountered the several minutes of flicker at 
breakpoints. I am relieved to to discover its cause. The crash, however, has 
only started occuring recently (in the last week), which was when I upgraded 
to 3.0M3. But I confirmed that the problem also happens in 3.0 M2. 

There is no telling how many editors I had open. I just now discovered that 
there is a preference setting for limiting the number of editor windows. I'm 
setting it to 8. Evidently, the default is to have no limit?
*** Bug 46525 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

No matter what I do, I get this exact problem about 10 minutes into debugging.  
It doesn't matter if I restart Eclipse, or close all editors.  It's impossible 
to develop.  I'm going to have to revert to an older version here.  I'm using 
M4, but I also encountered this on 2.1.2!  I'm using Win 98.

Not fixed in either 2.1.2 or 3.0M5 !!
What's up with that?
Maybe windows 98 is "limited" or whatever, but this is really bad.
I simply never had this problem before going to 2.1 and I do a lot of 
development on Eclipse.  I use WSAD at work, and have never once seen this 
problem but that's on WIN2000.

After reading through all the similar bugs, I tried removing my workspace 
directory, to let eclipse 3.0 M5 rebuild it entirely.  I then started eclipse, 
(with no workspace, just a completely new fresh one auto-created for me), then 
added some projects one at a time, and then in the middle of building the third 
project it gave me the out of handles thing, and bombed the exact same way 
everyone is describing.  So, it's completely unusable for me right now.  I'm at 
a dead stop.  Going back to 2.0 again - really sad.

There are some issues with Win 98, for example it runs out of Color handles 
very quickly, compared to Win2k for example.

There is a tool called "sleak" that helps find memory leaks like this, maybe 
it will help
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/swt-design-2/sleak.htm

This problem hasn't started for me until I upgraded to M6. In my case when it 
happens doesn't have to do anything with debugging. I just open some 
application in windows and the screen starts to flicker and crash and after a 
couple of minutes eclipse dies and things return to normal (almost, with some 
repainting errors). I have the aforementioned exception in the .log but I also 
discovered another interesting one:

I have a simple test case that I think repoduces this exact problem in every 3.0
version of eclispe that I have tried so far, including the latest version
available of 3.0.1. In the product I am developing the icons are used to flag
items on a table, so there are hundreds being produced every time the table
is refreshed. It is my understanding that the method used below should allow
me to get the icons as many times as I require without using up resouces.
However this test case shows this is not the case.

If needed I can e-mail people a zip containing the project. Please let me know
if you needs this. I will also try and attached the project to this defect as an
attachment.

I am running Windows XP, in 1280x1024, currently testing on eclipse 3.0.0
build 200406192000.

Test case is as follows:

Create a plugin project. Create a plugin project with the simple "hello world"
template which gives you a tool bar button that runs an action.

Replace the action code with the following:

   ImageDescriptor imgDescr = null;
    for (int k = 0; k < 10000; k++) {
      imgDescr = testIcons();
      Image i = imgDescr.createImage();
    }

The create the method testIcons() as follows, ensuring you have created the
static instance variable imageCount.

  private ImageDescriptor testIcons() {
    ImageDescriptor imgDesc = null;

    // look up the filename for the specified key
    String filename = "sample.gif";

    // look in ImageRegistry
    imgDesc =
HandlestestPlugin.getDefault().getImageRegistry().getDescriptor(filename);

    // if not found - load from file
    if (imgDesc == null) {
      try {
        String full_filename = "icons/" + filename; 
        Bundle bund = HandlestestPlugin.getDefault().getBundle();
        URL url = bund.getEntry(full_filename);
        imgDesc = ImageDescriptor.createFromURL(url);
      }
      catch (Exception e) {
        // in the event of an error, create a 'broken' icon instead
        imgDesc = ImageDescriptor.getMissingImageDescriptor();
      }

      // cache the new image
      HandlestestPlugin.getDefault().getImageRegistry().put(filename, imgDesc);
    }
    
    imageCount++;
    System.out.println(imageCount);
    
    return imgDesc;
  }

Running this test case I can produce 4894 icons every time before eclipse dies
with the no more handles error:

My example is simply pushing the number of images that can be loaded, the images
are not automatically disposed so rather than throwing away the images as I
expected from my sample code, they were simply consuming all available resources.

Changing the example to explicitly dispose of the images ensures that the "no
more handles" error does not occur.

I did some debugging many moons ago.

I found that there was a cache of images being kept, and never released.  For
some reason the same image would be keep being added to the cache.  From memory,
the cache was regularly flushed in such a way that the indexes were lost but the
images were not removed from the cache.  So the cache would contain thousands of
copies of a few hundred images.

I downloaded the then latest code to make a fix, and the offending cache was
gone.  So I upgraded, and I (for one) have not seen this problem since.

I've had the same "out of file handles" issue, but on Linux. The error has always occurred when I double-click a .java file to open in a new editor window. I have not been able to reliably reproduce the error, but feel it may be related to one of the following:

(1) opening & closing editor windows over many days of Eclipse use,
(2) or writing to the error logs (i.e. the logs associated with the dialogs that say "An error has occurred. See error log for more details.").

I strongly suspect (1) is not the problem, as there have been many times where I work for a couple of weeks without the crash, and others where it happens two days in a row.

I've been running with the -consolelog option, so I don't get the dialog error with (2). I also haven't has eclipse crash when using this option, but can't tell if it is just luck.

I also run in the debugger most of the time, which sounds similar to the issues described in previous posts.
